What a devil ails this fellow? this foolish fellow,
Being admitted to be one of us too,
That are the masters of the sports proceeding,
Thus to appear, before me too, unmorrissed?
Do you know me friend?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: You are my matters son, sir.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: And do you know what sports are now in season?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I hear there are some a foot.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Where are your bells then?
Your rings, your ribbons, friend? And your clean napkins?
Your nosegay in your hat, pinned up, am not I here?
My father's eldest son, and at this time, sir,
I would have ye know it, though ye be ten times his servant,
A better man than my father far, lord of this harvest, sir,
And shall a man of my place want attendance?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: 'Twas want of knowledge, sir, not duty, bred this,
I would have made suit else for your lordship's service.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: In some sort I am satisfied now, mend your manners,
But thou art a melancholy fellow, vengeance melancholy,
And that may breed a insurrection amongst us;
Go too, I'll lay the best part of two pots now
Thou art in love, and I can guess with whom too,
I saw the wench that twirled and twinkled at thee,
The other day; the wench that's new come hither,
The young smug wench.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: You know more than I feel sir.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Go too, I'll be thy friend, I'll speak a good word for thee,
And thou shalt have my lordship's countenance to her;
May be I have had a snap myself, may be I, may be no,
We lords are allowed a little more.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: 'Tis fit sir;
I humbly thank ye, you are too too tender of me,
But what sir, I beseech ye, was that paper,
Your lordship was so studiously employed in,
When ye came out a doors?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Thou meanest this paper.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: That sir, I think.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Why, 'tis a proclamation,
A notable piece of villainy, as ever thou heardest in thy life,
By mine honour it is.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: How sir? or what concerns it?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: It comes ye from the Duchess, a plaguy wise woman,
To apprehend the body of one Silvio,
As arrant a rascal as ever pissed against post,
And this same Silvio, or this foresaid rascal,
To bring before her, live or dead; for which good service
The man that brings him, has two thousand ducats;
Is not this notable matter now?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: 'Tis so indeed,
This proclamation bears my bane about it;
Can no rest find me? no private place secure me?
But still my miseries like bloodhounds haunt me?
Unfortunate young man, which way now guides thee,
Guides thee from death? the country's laid round for thee;
Oh Claudio, now I feel thy blood upon me,
Now it speaks loudly here, I am sure against me,
Time now has found it out, and truth proclaimed it,
And justice now cries out, I must die for it.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Hast thou read it?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: And dost thou know that Silvio.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I never saw him, sir.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: I have, and know him too,
I know him as well as I know thee, and better,
And if I light upon him, for a trick he played me once,
A certain kind of dogtrick, I'll so fiddle him,
Two thousand ducats, I'll so pepper him,
And with that money I'll turn gentleman,
Worth a brown bakers dozen of such Silvio's.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: There is no staying here, this rogue will know me,
And for the money's sake betray me too;
I must bethink me suddenly and safely.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Mine own dear lady, have at thy honeycomb,
Now, for the honour of our town, boys, trace sweetly,
What a vengeance ails this hubbub? pox refuse 'em,
Cannot they let us dance in our own defence here?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Arm, honest friends, arm suddenly and bravely,
And with your ancient resolutions follow me;
Look how the beacons show like comets, your poor neighbours
Run maddingly affrighted through the villages;
Sienna's Duke is up, burns all before him,
And with his sword, makes thousand mothers childless,

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: What's this to our morris-dancers?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: This may serve my turn.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: There's never a Duke in Christendom but loves a may-game.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: At a horse you were always ceased, put your son on him,
And arm him well i'th state's name, I command ye;
And they that dare go voluntary, shall receive reward.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: I dare go no way, sir, this is strange, master captain,
You cannot be content to spoil our sport here,
Which I do not think your worship's able to answer,
But you must set us together by the ears, with I know not who to?
We are for the bodily part o'th dance.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Arm him suddenly,
This is no time to fool, I shall return ye else,
A rebel to the general, state, and Duchess,
And how you'll answer then â€”

sp.speaker: Farmer
sp.l: I have no more sons, sir,
This is my only boy; I beseech ye master captain.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: I am a rank coward too, to say the truth, sir,
I never had good luck at buffets neither.

sp.speaker: Farmer
sp.l: Here's vorty shillings, spare the child.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Are ye a man? will ye cast away a may-lord?
Shall all the wenches in the country curse ye?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: An't please you captain, I'll supply his person,
'Tis pity their old custom should be frighted,
Let me have horse, and good arms, I'll serve willingly,
And if I shrink a foot of ground, hell take me.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: A promising aspect, face full of courage,
I'll take this man, and thank ye too.

sp.speaker: Farmer
sp.l: There's for thee,
'Tis in a clout, but good old gold.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I thank ye sir.

sp.speaker: Farmer
sp.l: Go saddle my fore-horse, put his feather on too,
He'll prance it bravely, friend, he fears no colours,
And take the armour down, and see him dizin'd,

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Farewell, and if thou carriest thyself well in this matter,
I say no more, but this, there must be more may-lords,
And I know who are fit.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Dance you, I'll fight, sir,

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Away, away.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Farewell, I am for the captain. Exit.

sp.speaker: Farmer
sp.l: Now to this matter again, my honest fellows,
For if this go not forward, I foresee friends,
This war will fright our neighbours out o'th villages;
Cheer up your hearts, we shall hear better news, boys.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Surely, I will dance no more, 'tis most ridiculous,
I find my wife's instructions now mere verities,
My learned wives, she often hath pronounced to me
My safety Bomby, defy these sports, thou art damned else,
This beast of Babylon, I will never back again,
His pace is sure profane, and his lewd wihies
The sons of Hymyn, and Gymyn, in the wilderness.

sp.speaker: Farmer
sp.l: Fie neighbour Bomby, in your fits again,
Your zeal sweats, this is not careful, neighbour,
The hobby-horse, is a seemly hobby-horse.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: And as pretty a beast on's inches, though I say it.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: The beast is an unseemly, and a lewd beast,
And got at Rome by the Pope's coach-horses,
His mother was the mare of ignorance.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Cobbler, thou liest, and thou wert a thousand cobblers,
His mother was an honest mare, and a mare of good credit,
I know the mare, and if need be, can bring witness;
And in the way of honesty I tell thee,
Scorned any coach-horse the Pope had, thou art foolish,
And thy blind zeal makes thee abuse the beast.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: I do defy thee, and thy foot-cloth too,
And tell thee to thy face, this profane riding
I feel it in my conscience, and I dare speak it,
This unedified ambling, hath brought a scourge upon us,
This hobby-horse sincerity we lived in
War, and the sword of slaughter: I renounce it,
And put the beast off; thus, the beast polluted,
And now no more shall hope on high Bomby,
Follow the painted pipes of worldly pleasures,
And with the wicked dance the devil's measures;
Away thou pampered jade of vanity,
Stand at the livery of lewd delights now,
And eat the provender of prick-eared folly,
My dance shall be to the pipe of persecution.

sp.speaker: Farmer
sp.l: Will you dance no more neighbour?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Surely no,
Carry the beast to his crib: I have renounced him,
And all his works.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Shall the hobby-horse be forgotten then?
The hopeful hobby-horse? shall he lie foundered?
If thou dost this, thou art but a castaway cobbler:
My anger's up, think wisely, and think quickly,
And look upon the quondam beast of pleasure,
If thou dost this (Mark me, thou serious Sowter)
Thou bench-whistler of the old tribe of toe-peeces,
If thou dost this there shall be no more shoe-mending,
Every man shall have a special care of his own soul:
And in his pocket carry his two confessors,
His Yugell, and his nawle: if thou dost this â€”

sp.speaker: Farmer
sp.l: He will dance again for certain.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: I cry out on't,
'Twas the fore-running sin brought in those tilt-staffs,
They brandish 'gainst the church, the devil calls maypoles,
Take up your horse again, and girth him to ye,
And girth him handsomely good neighbour Bomby.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: I spit at him.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Spit in the horse face, cobbler?
Thou out of tune-psalm-singing slave; spit in his visnomy?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: I spit again, and thus I rise against him:
Against this beast: that signified destruction,
Foreshowed ith' falls of monarchies.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Ith' face of him?
Spit such another spit, by this hand cobbler
I'll make ye set a new piece of your nose there,
'Take't up I say, and dance without more bidding,
And dance as you were wont: you have been excellent
And art still, but for this new nicety,
And your wives learned lectures: take up the hobby-horse
Come, 'tis a thing thou hast loved with all thy heart Bomby
And wouldst do still but for the round-breeched brothers:
You were not thus in the morning, take't up I say,
Do not delay but do it: you know I am officer,
And I know 'tis unfit all these good fellows
Should wait the cooling of your zealous porridge;
Choose whether you will dance, or have me execute:
I'll clap your neek ith' stocks, and there I'll make ye
Dance a whole day, and dance with these at night too,
You mend old shoes well, mend your old manners better,
And suddenly see you leave off this sincereness.
This new hot batch borrowed from some brown baker,
Some learned brother, or I'll so bait ye for't,
Take it quickly up.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: I take my persecution,
And thus I am forced a byword to my brothers.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Strike up, strike up: strike merrily.

sp.speaker: Farmer
sp.l: To it roundly,
Now to the harvest feast: then sport again boys.Exeunt

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: What shall I do? live thus unknown, and base still?
Or thrust myself into the head oth' battle?
And there, like that I am, a gentleman,
And one that never feared the face of danger,
(So in her angry eyes she carried honour)
Fight nobly, and (To end my cares) die nobly?
Silvio go on, and raise thy noble mind
To noble ends; fling course base thoughts behind:
Silvio, thou son of everliving fame,
Now aim at virtue, and a noble name.
Silvio consider, honour is not won,
Nor virtue reached, till some brave thing be done:
Thy country calls thee now; she burns, and bleeds,
Now raise thyself, young man, to noble deeds.
Into the battle Silvio, there seek forth
Danger, and blood, by them stands sacred worth.
What heavenly voice is this that follows me?
This is the second time 't has waited on me,
Since I was armed, and ready for the battle;
It names me often, steels my heart with courage,
And in a thousand sweet notes comforts me;
What beldom's this? how old she is, and ugly,
Why does she follow me?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Be not dismayed, son,
I wait upon thee, for thy good, and honour,
'Twas I that now sung to thee, stirred thy mind up,
And raised thy spirits to the pitch of nobleness.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Though she be old, and of a crooked carcase,
Her voice is like the harmony of angels.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Thou art my darling, all my love dwells on thee
The son of virtue, therefore I attend thee;
Inquire not what I am, I come to serve thee,
For if thou beest inquisitive, thou hast lost me:
A thousand long miles hence my dwelling is,
Deep in a cave, where but mine own, no foot treads,
There by mine art, I found what danger (Silvio)
And deep distress of heart, thou wert grown into,
A thousand leagues I have cut through empty air,
Far swifter than the sailing tack that gallops
Upon the wings of angry winds, to seek thee.
Sometimes o'er a swelling tide, on a dolphin's back I ride,
Sometimes pass the earth below, and through the unmoved centre go;
Sometimes in a flame of fire, like a meteor I aspire,
Sometimes in mine own shape, thus, when I help the virtuous,
Men of honourable minds, command my art in all his kinds;
Pursue the noble thought of war, from thy guard I'll not be far,
Get thee worship on thy foe, lasting fame is gotten so.
Single Sienna's Duke alone, hear thy friends, thy country groan,
And with thy manly arm strike sure, than thou hast wrought thine own free cure.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Some Sibyl sure, some soul heaven loves, and favours.
And lends her their free powers, to work their wonders?
How she incites my courage?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Silvio,
I knew thee many days ago ,
Foresaw thy love to Belvidere, the Duchess daughter, and her heir;
Knew she loved thee, and know what past, when you were found i'th castle fast
In one another's arms; foresaw the taking of ye, and the law;
And so thy innocence I loved, the deepest of my skill I proved;
Be ruled by me, for to this hour I have dwelled about thee with my power.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I will, and in the course of all observe thee,
For thou art sure an angel good sent to me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Get thee gone then to the fight, longer stay but robs thy right;
When thou growest weary I'll be near, then think on beauteous Belvidere,
For every precious thought of her, I'll lend thine honour a new spur;
When all is done, meet here at night; go and be happy in the fight. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I certainly believe I shall do nobly,
And that I'll bravely reach at too, or die. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena tertia.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Is she so loving still?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: She is mad with love,
As mad as ever unwormed dog was, signior,
And does so weep, and curse, for your prevention,
Your crosses in your love; it frets me too,
I am fallen away to nothing, to a spindle,
Grown a mere man of mat, no soul within me,
Pox of my master, sir, will that content ye?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: This rogue but cozens me, and she neglects me,
Upon my life there are some other gamesters,
Nearer the wind than I, and that prevents me,
Is there no other holds acquaintance with her?
Prithee be true, be honest, do not mock me,
Thou knowest her heart, no former interest
She has vowed a favour to? and cannot handsomely
Go off, but by regaining such a friendship?
There are a thousand handsome men, young, wealthy,
That will not stick at any rate, nor danger,
To gain so sweet a prize; nor can I blame her,
If where she finds a comfort she deal cunningly,
I am a stranger yet.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Ye are all she looks for,
And if there be any other, she neglects all,
And all for you: I would you saw how grievously
And with what hourly lamentations.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I know thou flatterest me; tell me but truth,
Look here, look well, the best meat in the dukedom,
The rarest, and the choicest of all diets,
This will I give thee, but to satisfy me;
That is, not to dissemble; this rare lobster,
This pheasant of the sea, this dish for princes,
And all this thou shalt enjoy, eat all thyself,
Have good Greek wine, or any thing belongs to it,
A wench if it desire one.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: All this, signior?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: All, and a greater far than this.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: A greater?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: If thou deserve by telling truth.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: A wench too?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Or any thing, but if you play the knave now,
The cozening knave besides the loss of this,
In which thou hast parted with a paradise,
I near will give thee meat more, not a morsel,
No smell of meat by my means shall come near thee,
Nor name of any thing that's nourishing,
But to thy old part Tantalus again,
Thou shalt return, and there snap at a shadow.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Upon this point, had I intended treason,
Or any thing might call my life in question,
Followed with all the tortures time could think on,
Give me but time to eat this lovely lobster,
This alderman o'th sea, and give me wine to him,
I would reveal all, and if that all were too little,
More than I knew; Bartello holds in with her,
The captain of the citadel, but you need not fear him,
His tongue's the stiffest weapon that he carries.
He is old, and out of use; there are some other,
Men young enough, handsome, and bold enough,
Could they come to make their game once; but they want sir,
They want the unde quare, they are laid by then,
You only are the man shall knock the nail in â€”

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: How now Penurio?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Your worship's fairly met, sir.
You shall hear further from me, steal aside sir.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Remember your master for those chains.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: They are ready, sir.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: What young thing's this? by his habit he's a merchant;
I fear he trades my way too, you dryed dogfish,
What bait was that?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Who sir, the thing went hence now?
A notable young whelp.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: To what end sirrah?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Came to buy chains and rings, is to be married,
An ass, a coxcomb, has nothing in his house, sir;
I warrant you think he came to see my mistress?

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: I doubt it shrewdly.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Away, away, 'tis foolish;
He has not the face to look upon a gentlewoman,
A poor skym'd thing, his mother's maids are fain, sir,
To teach him how to kiss, and against he is married,
To show him on which side the stirrup stands.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: That's a fine youth.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Thou wouldst hang thyself, that thou hadst half his power,
Thou empty potgun.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: Am I come fit Penurio?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: As fit as a fiddle,
My matter's now abroad about his business.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: When thou cam'st to me home today, I half suspected
My wife was jealous, that she whispered to thee.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: You deserve well the whilst, there's no such matter,
She talked about some toys my master must bring to her,
You must not know of.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: I'll take note, Penurio.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: No, nor you shall not, till you have it soundly.
This is the bravest capitano Pompo,
But I shall pump ye anon sir.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: O my Bartello?

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: Ye pretty rogue, you little rogue, you sweet rogue,
Away Penurio, go and walk i'th horse-fair.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: You do not love me?

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: Thou liest thou little rascal;
There sirrah, to your sentry.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: How the colt itches?
I'll help ye to a currycomb shall claw ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: And how much dost thou love me?

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: Let's go in quickly,
I'll tell thee presently, I'll measure it to thee.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: No busses first? sit o' my knee, my brave boy,
My valiant boy; do not look so fiercely on me,
Thou wilt fright me with thy face; come buss again chick,
Smile in my face you mad thing.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: I am mad indeed wench,
Precious I am all of fire.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I'll warrant thee better.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I'll warm thee too, or I'll blow out my bellows;
Ha, ye sweet rogue, you loving rogue, a boy now,
A soldier I will get shall prove a fellow.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Mistress, look to yourself, my master's coming.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: The devil come, and go with him.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: The devil's come indeed, he brings your wife, sir.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: We are undone, undone then.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: My wife with him?
Why this is a dismal day.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: They are hard by too, sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I must not, dare not see her.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Nor my husband,
For twenty thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: That I were a cat now,
Or any thing could run into a bench-hole,
Saint Anthony's fire upon the rogue has brought her;
Where shall I be? just in the nick oth' matter?
When I had her at my mercy: think for heaven's sake,
My wife, all the wild furies hell has.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Up the chimney.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: They'll smoke me out there presently.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: There, there, it must be there,
We are all undone else: it must be up the chimney.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Give me a ladder.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: You must use your art sir,
Alas, we have no ladders.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Pox of thy husband,
Does he never mend his house?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: No, nor himself neither:
Up nimbly sir, up nimbly.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thou knowest I am fat,
Thou merciless lean rogue.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Will ye be killed?
For if he take ye â€”

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Lend me thy shoulder.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Soft sir,
You'll tread my shoulder-bones into my sides else,
Have ye fast hold oth' bars?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: A vengeance bar 'em.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Patience good captain, patience: quickly, quickly.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Do you think I am made of smoke?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Now he talks of smoke,
What if my master should call for fire?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Will ye martyr me?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: He must needs have it.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Will ye make me bacon?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: We'll do the best we can, are all things ready?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: All, all, I have 'em all.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Go, let 'em in then,
Not a word now on your life.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I hang like a meteor.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: You are welcome lady.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: You are too too courteous,
But I shall make amends, fair Isabella.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Welcome my worthy friend, most kindly welcome.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: I hear on't, and I'll fit him for his foolery.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Some sweet meat's wife: some sweet meats presently.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: O my sour sauce.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Away quick Isabella. Exit Isab.
Did you hear him?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Yes, yes, perfectly, proceed sir.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Speak loud enough: dare ye at length but pity me?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: I'faith sir, you have used so many reasons to me,
And those so powerfully â€”

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Keep this kiss for me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And do I stand and hear this?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: This for me sir,
This is some comfort now: alas my husband â€”
But why do I think of so poor a fellow,
So wretched, so deboshed?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: That's I, I am bound to hear it.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: I dare not lie with him, he is so rank a whoremaster.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: And that's a dangerous point.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Upon my conscience sir,
He would stick a thousand base diseases on me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And now must I say nothing.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I am sound lady.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: That's it that makes me love ye.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Let's kiss again then.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Do, do.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Do, the devil.
And the grand pox do with ye.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Do ye hear him? well â€”
Now, what's the news with you?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: The sound of war sir,
Comes still along: the Duke will charge the city,
We have lost they say.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: What shall become of me then,
And my poor wealth?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Even hanged, I hope.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Remove your jewels presently,
And what you have of wealth into the citadel,
I hear all's secure.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I humbly thank ye lady:
Penurio, get me some can climb the chimney,
For there my jewels are, my best, my richest,
I hid 'em, fearing such a blow.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Most happily:
I have two boys, that use to sweep fouled chimneys,
Truly I brought 'em sir, to mock your worship,
For the great fires ye keep, and the full diet.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I forgive thee knave, where are they?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Here sir, here:
Monsieur black will your small worship mount?

sp.speaker: 1 boy.
sp.l: Madam Ã¨ be come to creep up into your chimney, and make you. Boy sings.
Clean, as any lady in de world: ma litla, litla frera, and Ã¨,
Chanta, frere, chanta.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Come monsieur, mount, mountÃ¨, mount monsieur Mustard-pot. Boy sings.

sp.speaker: 1 boy.
sp.l: Monsieur Ã¨ have dis for votra barba, ple ta von monsieur.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: MÃ²unte monsieur, mountÃ¨ dear be some fine tings.

sp.speaker: 1 boy.
sp.l: Me will creep like de ferret monsieur.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Dear in the chimney. The boy above singing.

sp.speaker: 1 boy.
sp.l: He be de shield due shauson, madam.

div.stage: Boy goes in behind the arras.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: There's a birds-nest, I wound have ye climb it monsieur,
Up my fine singing monsieur: that's a fine monsieur.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Watch him, he do not steal.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I warrant ye sir.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: These boys are knavish. Boy within, madam here be de rat, de rat madam.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I'll look to him tithly

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Lord, what comes here,Boy sings upon Bartella's shoulder.
A walking apparition?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Saint Christopher.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Mercy of me, what is it?
How like my husband it looks?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Get ye down devil,
I'll break your neck else: was ever man thus chimneyed?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Go pay the boys well: see them satisfied.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Come monsieur devils, come my blackberries
I'll butter ye of both sides.

div.stage: Boy exit saying, adieu madam, adieu madam.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Nay, e'en look sir, are you cooled now, captain?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I am cuckolded, and fooled to boot too:
Fooled fearfully, fooled shamefully.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: You are welcome sir,
I am glad I have any thing within these doors sir
To make ye merry; you love my wife, I thank ye,
You have showed your love.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Wife, am I this? this odd matter,
This monstrous thing?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: You ought, but yet you are not:
I have been bold with you sir, but yet not basely,
As I have faith I have not.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Sir, believe it;
'Twas all meant but to make you feel your trespass;
We new your hour, and all this fashioned for it.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Were you oth' plot too?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Yes by my troth, sweet captain.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You will forgive me wife?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: You will deserve it?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Put that toth' venture.

sp.speaker: Rho:
sp.l: Thus am I friends again then,
And as you never had gone astray, thus kiss ye.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And I'll kiss you, and you too ask forgiveness;
Kiss my wife Lopez, 'tis but in jest remember;
And now all friends together to my castle,
Where we'll all dine, and there discourse these storeys,
And let him be chimney-swept in's lust that glories. Exe.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Haile reverent dame, heaven wait upon thy studies.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You are well met son: what is the battle ended?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Mother, 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: How has thy honour prospered?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: The Duchess has the day, Syenna's prisoner:
Armed with thy powerful art, this arm dismounted him,
Received him then on foot, and in fair valour
Forced him mine own, this jewel I took from him,
It hung upon his cask, the victor's triumph:
And to the Duchess now a prisoner
I have rendered him: come off again unknown, mother.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: 'Tis well done, let me see he jewel son;
'Tis a rich one, curious set, fit a Princess burgonet:
This rich token late was sent, by the Duchess with intent
The marriage next day to begin: dost thou know what's hid within?
Wipe thine eyes, and then come near, see the beauteous Belvidere:
Now behold it.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: O my saint.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: We are it nobly, do not faint.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: How blessed am I in this rich spoil, this picture,
For ever will I keep it here, here mother,
For ever honour it: how oft, how chastely
Have I embraced the life of this, and kissed it?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: The day draws on that thou must home return,
And make thy answer to the Duchess quest on
I know it troubles thee, for if thou fail in't â€”

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: O, I must die.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Fear not, fear not, I'll be nigh,
Cast thy trouble on my back, art nor cunning shall not lack
To preserve thee, still to keep, what thy envious foemen seek;
Go boldly home, and let thy mind, no distrustful crosses find:
All shall happen for the best; souls walk through sorrows that are blessed.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Then I go confident.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: But first my son, a thankful service must be done,
The good old woman for her pain, when every thing stands fair again,
Must ask a poor boon, and that granting, there's nothing to thy journey wanting.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Except the trial of my soul to mischief,
And as I am a knight, and love mine honour,
I grant it whatsoever.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Thy pure soul
Shall never sink for me, nor howl.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Then any thing.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: When I shall ask remember.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: If I forget, heaven's goodness forget me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: On thy journey then a while, to the next cross way and style
I'll conduct thee, keep thee true, to thy mistress and thy vow,
And let all their envies fall, I'll be with thee and quench all.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Lady, the stubborn war's more mild than you are,
That allows ransom, and the prisoner taken â€”

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: We must not be too hasty: remember sir,
The wrong and violence you have offered us,
Burned up our frontier towns, made prey before ye
Both of our beasts, and corn; slain our dear subjects,
Opened the fountain eyes of thousand widows,
That daily fling their curses on your fury;
What ordinary satisfaction can salve this?
What hasty thought-on ransom give a remedy?
You must excuse us yet, we'll take more counsel:
In the mean time, not as a prisoner,
But as a noble prince we entertain ye.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: I am at your mercy lady, 'tis my fortune,
My stubborn fate; the day is yours, you have me,
The valour of one single man has crossed me,
Crossed me and all my hope; for when the battles
Were at the hottest game of all their furies,
And conquest ready then to crown me victor,
One single man broke in, one sword, one virtue,
And by his great example thousands followed,
Oh how I shame to think on't, how it shakes me!
Nor could our strongest head then stop his fury,
But like a tempest 'Bear the field before him,
Till he arrived at me, with me he buckled,
A while I held him play; at length his violence
Beat me from my saddle, then on foot pursued me,
There triumphed once again, then took me prisoner:
When I was gone a fear possessed my people.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: One single arm, in a just cause, heaven prospers.
Is not this stranger knight as yet discovered,
That we may give his virtue a due honour?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Not yet that we hear madam, but to that purpose,
Two days ago we published proclamations

div.stage: Enter Soto with a trumpet, and Silvio.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: O dainty Duchess, here I bring that knight
Before thy fragrant face, that warlike wight,
He that Syenna's Duke, and all his louts
Beat (As the proverb seemly says) to clouts:
He that unhorsed the man of fame to boot,
And bootless taught his grace to walk afoot:
He that your writings (Packed to every pillar)
Promised promotion to, and store of filler,
That very man I set before thy grace,
And once again pronounce this man it was.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: A pretty foolish squire, what must the knight be?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Some juggler, or some madman.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I was not so,
When thy faint troops in flocks I beat before me,
When through the thickest of thy warlike horse
I shot myself, even to thy standard Duke,
And there found thee, there singled thee, there showed thee
The temper of my sword. 'tis true, thou stoodst me,
And like a noble soldier bid'st me welcome;
And this I'll say, more honour in that arm
I found and tried, than all thy army carried:
What follows thy imprisonment can tell thee.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: His fair relation carries truth and virtue,
And by those arms I see (For such were his,
So old, so rusty) this may be he that forced me.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Do you know this jewel, from your cask I rent it,
Even as I closed, and forced ye from your saddle;
Do you now remember me?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: This is the valour
Madam, for certain he, it must be he,
That day I wore this jewel, you remember it.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Yes, very well; not long before I sent it.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: That day I lost this jewel, in fight I lost it,
I felt his strokes, and felt him take it from me,
I wore it in my cask; take it again sir,
You won it nobly, 'tis the prize of honour.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: My father, and myself are made for ever.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Kneel down brave sir, thus my knight first I raise ye,
Gird on a sword; next general of my army,
Give him a staff; last, one in counsel near me.
Now, make us happy with your sight: how? Silvio?
Have I on thee bestowed this love, this honour?
The treasons thou hast wrought set off with favours?
Unarm him presently: oh thou foul traitor,
Traitor to me, mine honour, and my country,
Thou kindler of these wars.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Mistake not madam.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Away with him to prison,
See him safe kept, the law shall shortly sirrah,
Find fitter titles for ye, than I gave ye.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: This is the youth that killed me, I'll be quit with him,
What a blind rogue was I, I could never know him?
An't please your grace, I claim the benefit
Of the proclamation that proclaimed him traitor,
I brought him in.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Thou shalt have thy reward for't.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Let him be hanged, or drowned then.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Madam, I crave your promise first; you are tied to it,
You have passed your princely word.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Prove it, and take it.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: This is the day appointed,
Appointed by your grace for my appearance,
To answer to the question.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I remember it.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I claim it then,

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: If you perform it not,
The penalty you claim too.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I not repent it;
If I absolve the words?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Your life is free then,
You have drawn a speedy course above my wishes,
To my revenge, be sure ye hit it right,
Or I'll be sure you shall not scape the danger.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: My rest is up now madam.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Then play it cunningly.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Now, where's the hag? where now are all her promises,
She would be with me, strengthen me, inform me?
My death will now be double death, ridiculous:
She was wont still to be near, to feel my miseries,
And with her art, I see her nowhere now;
What have I undertaken? now she fails me,
No comfort now I find, how my soul staggers?
Till this hour never fear, nor doubt possessed me,
She cannot come, she will not come, she has fooled me;
Sure, she is the devil, has drawn me on to ruin,
And now to death bequeathes me in my danger.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: He stands distracted, and his colour changes.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I have given him that will make his blood forsake him;
Shortly his life.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: His hands and contemplation
Have motion still, the rest is earth already.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Come, will ye speak or pray? your time grows out sir;
How everywhere he looks? he's at last cast.

div.stage: Enter Belvidere, and secretly gives him a paper, and exit.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: His colour comes again fresh.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: 'Tis a flash, sir,
Before the flame burns out; can ye yet answer?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Yes madam, now I can.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I fear you'll fail in't.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: And do not think my silence a presage,
Or omen to my end, you shall not find it;
I am bred a soldier, not an orator,
Madam, peruse this scroll, let that speak for me,
And as you are royal, wrong not the construction.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: By heaven you shall have fair play.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I shall look for't.
Tell me what it that only thing,
For which all women long;
Yet having what they most desire,
To have it does them wrong.
'Tis not to be chaste, nor fair,
Such gifts malice may impair;
Richly trimmed, to walk or ride,
Or to wanton unespied;
To preserve an honest name,
And so to give it up to fame;
These are toys. In good or ill
They desire, to have their will;
Yet when they have it, they abuse it,
For they know not how to use it.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: You have answered right, and gained your life,
I give it.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: O happy hag! But my most gracious madam,
Your promise tide a nobler favour to me.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: 'Tis true, my daughter too.

sp.speaker: Sil
sp.l: I hope you will keep it.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: 'Tis not in my power now, she is long since wandered,
Stolen from the court, and me; and what I have not
I cannot give: no man can tell me of her,
Nor no search find her out: and if not Silvio,
Which strongly I believe â€”

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Mock me not lady,
For as I am a servant to her virtue,
Since my first hour of exile, I never saw her

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: That she is gone 'tis too too true, and lamentable,
Our last hope was in you.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: What do I hear then,
And wherefore have I life bestowed and honour?
To what end do I walk? for men to wonder at,
And fight, and fool? pray ye take your honours from me,
(My sorrows are not fit companions for 'em)
And when ye please my life: art thou gone mistress,
And wanderest heaven knows where? this vow I make thee,
That till I find thee out, and see those fair eyes,
Those eyes that shed their lights, and life into me,
Never to know a friend, to seek a kindred,
To rest where pleasure dwells, and painted glory,
But through the world, the wide world thus to wander,
The wretched world alone, no comfort with me,
But the mere meditations of thy goodness:
Honour and greatness, thus adieu.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Stay Silvio,
And lady sit again, I come for justice.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: What would she now?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: To claim thy promise Silvio,
The boon thou sworest to give me.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: What may this be,
A woman, or a devil?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: 'Tis a witch sure,
And by her means he came to untwist this riddle,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: That I am bound to her for my life, mine honour,
And many other thousand ways for comfort
I here confess: confess a promise too,
That what she would ask me to requite these favours,
Within the endeavour of my life to grant,
I would; and here I stand my words full master.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I wish no more: great lady, witness with me,
The boon I crave for all my service to thee,
Is now to be thy wife, to grant me marriage.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: How? for to marry thee? ask again woman,
Thou wilful woman, ask again.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No more sir.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Ask land, and life.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I ask thee for a husband.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Marry her, and beat her into gunpowder,
She would make rare crackers.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Ask a better fortune,
Thou art too old to marry: I a soldier,
And always married to my sword.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Thy word fool,
Break that, and I'll break all thy fortunes yet.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: He shall not,
I am witness to his faith: and I'll compel it.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: 'Tis fit ye hold your word, sir.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: O most wretched.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: This was a fortune now beyond my wishes,
For now my daughter's free, if e'er I find her.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: But not from me.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: You are sharer in this happiness,
Myself will wait upon this marriage,
And do the old woman all the honour possible.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: I'll lead the knight, and what there wants in dalliance,
We'll take it out in drink.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: O wretched Silvio. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Hast thou sent for him?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Yes,

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: A young man, sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Yes, very young, and very amorous.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: And handsome?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: As the town affords.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: And dar'st thou
Be so far good, and mistress of thine honour,
To sleight these?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: For my husband's sake to curse 'em,
And since you have made me mistress of my fortune,
Never to point at any joy, but husband,
I could have cozened ye, but so much I love ye,
And now so much I weigh the estimation
Of an unspotted wife â€”

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I dare believe thee,
And never more shall doubt torment my spirit.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: How now Penurio?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: The thing is coming, mistress.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I'll take my standing.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Do, and I'll take mine. Exit Lopes.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Where didst thou leave him?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I left him in a cellar,
Where he has paid me tightly, paid me home mistress,
We had an hundred and fifty healths to you, sweet mistress,
And three score and ten damnations to my master;
Mistress, shall I speak a foolish word to ye?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: What's that Penurio?
The fellow's drunk.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I would fain know your body.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: How's that? how's that prithee?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I would know it carnally,
I would conglutinate.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: The reason sirrah?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Lobster, sweet mistress, lobster.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Thy master hears.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Lobster, sweet master, lobster.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Thou art the most precious rogue.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Most precious lobster.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Do you see who's here? go sleep ye drunken rascal.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Remember you refuse me armed in lobster. Exit.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: O my lost Rugio, welcome, welcome, welcome,
A thousand welcomes here I'll seal.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Pray ye stay, lady,
Do you love me ever at this rate? or is the fit now,
By reason of some wrong done by your husband,
More fervent on ye?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Can I choose but love thee?
Thou art my martyr, thou hast suffered for me,
My sweet, sweet Rugio.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Do you do this seriously?
'Tis true, I would be entertained thus.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: These are nothing,
No kisses, no embraces, no endearments,
To those â€”

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Do what you will.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Those that shall follow,
Those I will crown our love withal; why sigh ye?
Why look ye sad my dear one?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nay faith nothing,
But methinks so sweet a beauty, as yours shows to me,
And such an innocence as you may make it,
Should hold a longer siege.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Ha, you speak truth, sir.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I would not have it so.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: And now methinks,
Now I consider truly what becomes me,
I have been cozened, fearfully abused,
My reason blinded.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nay, I did but jest with ye.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I'll take ye at your word, and thank ye for't sir;
And now I see no sweetness in that person,
Nothing to stir me to abuse a husband,
To ruin my fair fame.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Good Isabella.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: No handsome man, no any thing to dote on,
No face, no tongue to catch me, poor at all points,
And I an ass.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Why do ye wrong me lady?
If I were thus, and had no youth upon me,
My service of so mean a way to win ye,
(Which you yourself are conscious must deserve ye,
If you had thrice the beauty you possess, must reached ye)
If in my tongue your fame lay wracked, and ruined
With every cup I drink: if in opinion
I were a lost, defamed man: but this is common
Where we love most, where most we stake our fortunes,
There least and basest we are rewarded: fare ye well,
Know now I hate you too as much, contemn ye,
And weigh my credit at as high a value.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: May be I did but jest.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Ye are a woman,
And now I see your wants, and mine own follies,
And task myself with indiscretion,
For doting on a face so poor.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Say ye so sir,
(I must not lose my end) I did but jest with you,
Only fooled thus to try your faith: my Rugio,
Do you think I could forget?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis no matter.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Is't possible I should forsake a constancy,
So strong, so good, so sweet?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: A subtle woman.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: You shall forgive me, 'twas a trick to try ye,
And were I sure ye loved me â€”

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Do you doubt now?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I do not doubt, but he that would profess this,
And bear that full affection you make show of,
Should do â€”

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What should I do?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I cannot show ye.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I'll try thee damnedest devil: hark ye lady,
No man shall dare do more, no service top me,
I'll marry ye.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Your husbands sentenced,
And he shall die.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Die?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Die for ever to ye,
The danger is mine own.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Die did ye tell me?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: He shall die, I have cast the way.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: O foul man,
Malicious bloody man.

sp.speaker: Lop,
sp.l: When shall he die sir,
By whom, and how?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Hast thou betrayed me, woman?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Base man, thou wouldst have ruined me, my name too,
And like a toad, poisoned my virtuous memory:
Further than all this, dost thou see this friend here,
This only friend, shame take thy lust and thee,
And shake thy soul, his life, the life I love thus,
My life in him, my only life thou aimedst at.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Am I catch's thus?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: The law shall catch ye better.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: You make a trade of betraying women's honours,
And think it noble in ye to be lustful,
Report of me hereafter â€”

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Fooled thus finely?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I must entreat ye walk, sir, to the justice,
Where if he'll bid ye kill me â€”

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Pray stay a while, sir,
I must use a player's shift, do you know me now lady?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Your brother Claudio sure.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: O me, 'tis he sir,
Oh my best brother.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: My best sister now too,
I have tried ye, found ye so, and now I love ye,
Love ye so truly nobly.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Sir, I thank ye,
You have made me a most happy man.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Thank her sir,
And from this hour preserve that happiness,
Be no more fooled with jealousy.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I have lost it,
And take me now new born again, new natured.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I do, and to that promise tie this faith,
Never to have a false thought tempt my virtue.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Enough, enough, I must desire your presence,
My cousin Rhodope has sent in all haste for us,
I am sure you will be welcome.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I'll wait on ye.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: What the project is â€”

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: We shall know when we are there, sir. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena tertia.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Joy to you Silvio, and your young fair bride,
You have stolen a day upon us; you cannot woo sir.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: The joys of hell hang over me, oh mischief,
To what a fortune has the devil driven me?
Am I reserved for this?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Beshrew me sir,
But you have gotten you a right fair bedfellow,
Let you alone to choose.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I beseech your grace,
'Tis misery enough to have met the devil,
Not men's reproaches too.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: How old is she?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: A very girl, her eye delivers it.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Her teeth are scarce come yet.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: What goodly children
Will they two have now? she is rarely made to bread on,
What a sweet timbered body?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Knotty i'th back,
But will hold out the stronger; what a nose?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: I marry, such a nose, so rarely mounted,
Upon my conscience, 'twas the part he doted on.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: And that fine little eye to it, like an elephants.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Yes, if her feet were round, and her ears satchels.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: For any thing we know.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Have ye no mercy?
No pity in your bloods, to use a wretch thus?
You princes, in whose hearts the best compassions,
Nearest to those in heaven, should find fit places,
Why do you mock at misery? Fling scorns and baseness
Upon his broken back, that sinks with sorrows?
Heaven may reward you too, and an hour come,
When all your great designs shall show ridiculous,
And your hearts pinched like mine.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Fie sir, so angry
Upon your wedding day? go smug yourself,
The maid will come anon: what music's this?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: I warrant you some noble preparation.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Let's take our places then.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: More of these devil's dumps?
Must I be ever haunted with these witchcrafts?

div.stage: Enter a masquerado of several shapes and dances, after which enter Belvidere and disperses them, before the maskers enter two presenters, among which are Bartello, Lopez, Claudio, Isabella, Rhodope, Soto, Penurio, Jaquenet.

sp.speaker: 1. Pre.
sp.l: Room, room for merry spirits, room,
Hither on command we come,
From the good old beldame sent,
Cares and sorrows to prevent.
Look up Silvio, smile, and sing,
After winter comes a spring.
Fear not faint fool what may follow,
Eyes that now are sunk and hollow,
By her art may quick return
To their flames again, and burn.
Art commands all youth, and blood,
Strength and beauty it makes good.
Fear not then, despair not, sing
Round about as we do spring:
Cares and sorrows cast away,
This is the old wife's holiday.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Who is this?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: The shape of Belvidere.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Now Silvio,
How dost thou like me now?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Thus I kneel to thee.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Stand up, and come no nearer, mark me well too,
For if thou troublest me I vanish instantly:
Now choose wisely or choose never,
One thou must enjoy for ever.
Dost thou love me thus?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Most dear.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Take heed fool, it concerns thee nearly.
If thou wilt have me young and bright,
Pleasing to thine eye and sight,
Courtly, and admired of all,
Take heed lest thy fame do fall,
I shall then be full of scorn,
Wanton, proud, beware the horn,
Hating what I loved before,
Flattery apt to fall before,
All consuming, nothing getting,
Thus thy fair name comes to setting.
But if old and free from these
Thou shalt choose me, I shall please:
I shall then maintain thee still,
With my virtue and my skill:
Still increase and build thy name,
Choose now Silvio, here I am.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I know not what to say, which way to turn me,
Into thy sovereign will I put my answer.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I thank ye sir, and my will thus rewards ye,
Take your old love, your best, your dearest Silvio:
No more spells now, nor further shapes to alter me,
I am thy Belvidere indeed, dear mother,
There is no altering this; heavens hand is with it:
And now you ought to give me, he has fairly won me.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: But why that hag?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: In that shape most secure still,
I followed all your fortunes, served, and counselled ye,
I met ye at the farmers first a country wench,
Where fearing to be known I took that habit,
And to make ye laughing sport at this mad marriage,
By secret aid of my friend Rhodope
We got this mask.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: And I am sure I have ye.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: For ever now, for ever.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: You see it must be,
The wheel of destiny hath turned it round so.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: It must, it is, and cursed be he that breaks it.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I'll put a choice to you sir: ye are my prisoner.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: I am so, and I must be so, till it please you â€”

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Choose one of these, either to pay a ransom,
At what rate I shall set it, which shall be high enough,
And so return a freeman, and a bachelor,
Or give me leave to give you a fit wife,
In honour every way your grace's equal,
And so your ransom's paid.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: You say most nobly,
Silvio's example's mine, pray choose you for me.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I thank ye sir, I have got the mastery too,
And here I give your grace a husband's freedom,
Give me your hand, my husband.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: You much honour me,
And I shall ever serve ye for this favour.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: Come Lopez, let us give our wives the breeches too,
For they will have 'em.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Whilst they rule with virtue
I'll give 'em, skin and all.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: We'll scratch it off else.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I am glad ye live, more glad ye live to honour,
And from this hour a stronger love dwell with us;
Pray you take your man again.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: He knows my house sir.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: 'Tis sin to keep you longer from your loves,
We'll lead the way; and you young men that know not
How to preserve a wife, and keep her fair,
Give 'em their sovereign wills, and pleased they are. Exeunt.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
